entry.def: Notes: stubble land.
Notes: see Taingealachd, Tàmh and Ceisd.
Quotation: lachan gàire. Notes: loud burst of laughter.
Quotation: ciste-laighe.
[ɫɑ:ɾvu̜əɫt̪ə] Notes: like a wooden door. Used for threshing corn. (Says this is the only instance in which “làr” is used.)
[lʹɤu̟ɾɑxkĩnʹ] Notes: “betrothal”, same as “réiteach”. (Liubhair?)
Notes: a window pane.
[lʹiɤɾɔɡ] Notes: hoar frost.
[lʹiɑɑɡ] Notes: trout. Dw. gives it as salmon-trout or grilse.
[ɫɔ:pɑ̃ṉ] Notes: a large basket on wheels drawn by horses. Also càrn-lòpan.
[ɫɔ] Notes: up to three years old.
[ɫɤsɡən̪] Notes: frog.
Notes: otter.
[mɑ̃d̪əru̜ɤɣ] Notes: fox.
Notes: bridesmaid.
Notes: harvest maiden. [kɫɑ̃iɑɡ] also heard by Donald.
Notes: beadle.
[mɛ̃ṉɑxu̟lɑɡ] Notes: midge.
[mɛliç] Quotation: Bha e gu meileachdainn leis an fhuachd. Notes: “He was almost numbed by the cold.”
Quotation: a’ mhial [əvĩɔɫ]. Notes: ailment in horses which involves the top gum extending downwards. Has to be cut or burned.
[mĩɤ̃ṉɑṉ] Notes: a yawn.
[mĩɤ̃n̪ɑṉiç] Notes: yawning.
Quotation: Coinneamh Mhios [kɔnʹi vĩɑ̃s]. Notes: monthly meeting.
[mĩt̪ɑɡ] Notes: glove.
[mu̜ləṉ ɫɑ̃iv] Notes: hand threshing-mill. One person turned the handle and the person who put in the corn worked the pedals.
[mũ̟lɑçĩnʹ] Notes: a sleeve.
[rɑbɑdʹ] Notes: rabbit.
[rɛ:] Quotation: Coinneamh Ràith [kɔnʹirɛ:]. Notes: seasonal meeting.
Quotation: an riarachdainn. Notes: biscuits, cheese and whisky given to those who attended a funeral.
Quotation: Righle Thuluchainn. Notes: Reel of Tulloch.
[rɔ:kiʃ] Notes: raven.
Notes: a small potato.
Notes: resin.
[ru̜:xkɑṉ] Notes: small temporary stack made on the field. Only made if the weather was rather wet.
[ɑhərɫə] Notes: a heifer.
[ʃit̪əɾiç] Quotation: Tha an each a’ sitrich. Notes: neighing. Sitrich (n): a neigh.
Quotation: Bha e air thurraban. Notes: rocking motion.
Notes: shoe-lace.
Notes: dung.
[jw̃ɣĩnʹ] Notes: a fingernail.
[jw̃:ɾiç] Quotation: Tha e air [jw̃:ɾəxkĩnʹ]. Notes: it has festered.
Quotation: droch isean. Notes: “a bad stick” – used of a person.
Notes: bobbin (probably the one inserted in shuttle for weaving).
[n̪ɑ̃ĩɔl] Quotation: Tha e naimheal. Notes: “It is bitterly cold.”
[n̪ɑ̃ĩɑ̃l] Quotation: duine naimheil. Notes: a very spiteful, nasty person.
[ṉɑ̃həʴnʹɛ̃] Notes: snake. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
[nʹɛ̃:piɡʹ] Notes: handkerchief.
[nʹw̃s] Notes: weasel.
[elɑṉ] Quotation: “Nach ann air a tha an droch oilean.” Notes: bad-mannered.
[elɑṉəx] Notes: well-mannered.
Quotation: na h-òrduighean.
Notes: manure heap.
[pesɑṉ] Notes: impudent fellow.
[peliʃtʹɑɾəṉ] Notes: quoits.
[piɑʴsɑd] Quotation: na peursaidean. Notes: warble-fly. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
Quotation: Fhuair thu “cuireadh a phìobaire”. Notes: “You can come to the wedding if you want to.” See Dw.
[plɛ:ḏ] Notes: plaid worn by women.
[poɫəvɑ̃:ɡɑ̃ṉ] Notes: a toad.
[pɔ̃ṉɑx] Notes: a lad, up to, say, 14 years old. More commonly used than “balach”.
[sɤu̟t̪əɾ] Notes: solder.
[sɑxk] Quotation: Bha sac mór air an each. Notes: load.
[sɤ:vi] Notes: a den.
[ʃɛ̃ɣɑ̃ṉ] Notes: ant.
Notes: foal.
[ʃɛskɔt] Notes: waistcoat.
[ʃɛhɑ̃ṉ] Quotation: Bha seathan air. Notes: He was panting.
[ʃeliçɑɡ] Notes: snail.
[ʃɔɔɡ] Notes: hawk.
Notes: a resounding slap.
[sɡɑʰstʹɑl] [?] Notes: well-built.
[sɡɑɾɑɫɑx] Notes: area of loose stones, e.g. on a hillside. Dw. see “garbhalach”.
[sɡʹelɑdʹ] Notes: a saucepan.
Quotation: sgian mhóine.
[sɡʹiləɡ] Notes: the husk taken off the grain before grinding.
[sɡiləɡ] Quotation: a’ sgileadh. Notes: shelling grain.
[sɡliɑt̪ɑɡ] Notes: slater.
Notes: a light cuff with the back of the hand.
[sɡob] Quotation: “Sgob i mi.” Notes: It stung me.
[sɡoltʹʃɑ̃ṉ] Notes: the half of a potato with an “eye” in it. Planted.
[sɡɾɛd̪əɫɑ̃ṉdʹɛɾɑɡ] Notes: an area of finely broken red stone.
[sɡɾisɑṉ] Notes: wedding dress.
[sɡɾu̜:ɑ̃ṉ] Notes: stook (Black Isle).
[sɡu̜:ɫɑṉ] Notes: a basket for holding potatoes.
[ʃiɑpəɾə] Quotation: siapaire gille. Notes: lazy, slow-moving.
[ʃiɑpəɾə] Notes: dawdler, slow-moving person.
Notes: second grade seeds (corn, etc.). (Probably potatoes, too.)
Quotation: pl. siollachan. Notes: haimes.
Quotation: a’ ghaoth shios. Notes: the east wind.
Notes: a horse-drawn sledge.
Quotation: Chaidh e ’na smàl. Notes: It went into smithereens or it went on fire.
Quotation: Fhuair e smàladh. Notes: extreme physical punishment.
Notes: chin.
[smɛ̃ɾ] Notes: marrow.
Quotation: smùrach na moine.
[sn̪w̃:ʃɑṉ] Notes: snuff.
[sɔxk] Notes: “sock” of plough.
[sɔxɑɾɔx] Notes: shy, timid.
Notes: heather dish and pot scourer.
[spe:l] Notes: a slide.
[spe:l] Quotation: Bha mi a’ spéileadh air an deigh. Notes: sliding.
[spe:ləɣu̜rəxɑ̃ṉ] Notes: sliding on ice with bended knees, the person sliding being pulled along by each hand by two persons flanking him.
Notes: the joint on a horse’s hind leg corresponding to the knee.
Notes: spoke of a wheel.
[spɔɾəs] Notes: sparrow.
Quotation: Nach uamhasach a’ spùt a th’aige. Notes: said of a garrulous person.
[sɾɑhəɾ] Notes: cart-saddle.
Quotation: an t-srian. Notes: the bridle of the plough. (See also cluasag – DMM.)
Notes: a mixture of oatmeal and cold water.
[ʃtʹu̜ɫəɡ] Quotation: Bha e a stiulladh an uisge. Notes: splashing about. (Prob. from “steall”.)
[ʃtʹu̜:rɑɡ] Notes: a little oatmeal, a spoonful of milk and boiling water added.
[st̪ɾɑ̃ũ̜n̪] Notes: snore.
[st̪ɾw̃ɣɑṉ] Notes: string used for sewing shoes.
[st̪ɾɔt̪] Notes: a sneeze.
Quotation: a’ strotaich. Notes: sneezing.
[st̪ɾɔt̪ɑṉ] Notes: a sneeze.
Quotation: a’ ghaoth shuas. Notes: the west wind.
Quotation: an teasach scàrlaid. Notes: scarlet fever.
Quotation: Là Taingealachd an fhoghair. Notes: 2nd Wednesday of November.
[t̪ɑɫu̜ t̪ɾɔ] Notes: cultivated or arable land.
Quotation: Là tàimh. Notes: Thursday of Communions.
Notes: able, capable.
[t̪ɑɾɑɡ] Quotation: tarag cliath. Notes: spike of harrows.
[t̪ɑɾɑvn̪ɑərnʹɛ̃] Notes: dragonfly.
[t̪ɑrıɡʹ] Quotation: An do tharraig an tea?
[t̪ɑrĩnʹəṉ] Notes: drag-chains.
Quotation: an teasach scàrlaid. Notes: scarlet fever.
Notes: a house in which a wake is being held.
Quotation: a’ tilgeil a’ chabair. Notes: tossing the caber.
Notes: a funeral.
[t̪ɔxɾəɣ] Notes: dowry.
Quotation: Bha iad a’ todhair an aodaich. Notes: bleach clothes by laying them outside on the grass.
Quotation: toll buntàta [t̪ɤu̜ɫ bwṉɑ:t̪ə]. Notes: potato pit.
[t̪ɔrɔʃcɑṉ] Notes: peat-cutting iron.
Notes: a small hillock.
Notes: trousers.
[t̪u̟ʃəlʹɑ̃ṉ] Quotation: “Bha tuislean aca ’san tigh sin.” Notes: There was a birth in that house. Dw. tuislich: bring forth, bear.
[t̪u̜ɫu̜xɑ̃ṉ] Notes: a small hillock.
Quotation: Righle Thuluchainn. Notes: Reel of Tulloch.
[t̪u̟ɾəɡ] Quotation: Tha turadh ann. Notes: It has stopped raining.
[t̪u̜ru̜bɑ̃ṉ] Quotation: Tha e air thurraban. Notes: rocking motion.
[u̜nʹĩdʹ]
[u̜lĩnʹ] Notes: elbow.
Quotation: Tha e coltach ris an uisg. Notes: “It looks as if it is going to rain.”
[u̜:rɫəsɡəɣ] Notes: heartburn.
[u̜ʴsĩnʹ] Notes: doorpost. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
[ɤɾəxkɑn] Notes: lapwing. For “adharcan”.
[ɤəst̪əɾ] Notes: horse halter made of twisted birch wands.
Notes: kidney.
[ɑtʹɑɫ] Quotation: Chaneil aiteal ann. Notes: “There isn’t a whit there.”
[ɔ̃hiç] Notes: neck. [NOTES: slipped under ‘amhaich’.]
[ɛ̃ṉɑɫ] Quotation: Leig e [ɛ̃ṉɑɫ]. Notes: He took a rest.
[ɑɾəd̪hɑɫɑĩnʹ] Notes: winding shroud.
[ɑ:rɫəs] Notes: hole in the roof of thatched houses to allow an exit for smoke.
[ɑhəʴṉɑx] Notes: ground in which potatoes were planted the previous year. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
[bɤu̜t̪] Notes: a swathe.
Notes: earmark. “Beum-spaid” also used for this earmark.
Quotation: cuireadh na bainns’. Notes: wedding invitation.
Quotation: bean na bainnse. Notes: bride.
Quotation: fear na bainnse. Notes: bridegroom.
[bɑ:rɡu̜:ɡ] Notes: blossoms growing on potato shaws.
Quotation: bean na bainnse. Notes: bride.
[bjɑʴstʹ] Notes: loom. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
Notes: earmark. “Bacan” also used.
[biɾiç] Notes: a foal after it has stopped suckling.
[bwsɡɑdʹ] Notes: biscuit.
[bobɑɡ] Notes: Donald says he heard his mother using this word for “stepfather”.
[pɤu̜lə] Notes: a bowl.
Quotation: bocsa na cuibhle. Notes: hub or nave of wheel.
Notes: scarecrow.
Quotation: 2. boinnean tea. 3. Bha e déigheil air a’ bhoinnein. Notes: 1. a drop. 2. a “drop” of tea. 3. He was fond of the “cratur”.
[boʃ] Notes: palm.
Notes: earth-board in a plough.
[bɔ:d̪] Notes: a boot.
[bɾɑ:dʹ] Notes: collar for young horses made of twisted fodder.
Notes: weaver.
[bɾɛxkəɣbeɡ] Notes: speckled pattern made by wispy clouds in the sky.
[bɾɛxkɑ̃ṉ] Notes: plaid formerly worn by men.
Quotation: Bha e [bɾɛxk] air. Notes: He was catching it. (As if an abbrev. of “breitheachd”.)
[bɾıɡıʃ] Notes: breeches, tied at the knee.
Notes: breeching.
Notes: made from steeped oatmeal, boiled with milk. A thin mixture.
[bɾu̜:jɛɾɑɡ] Notes: robin redbreast.
[bɾu̟əs] Quotation: Bha bruthas aige ’s a’ mhonadh. Notes: a bothy for making illicit whisky.
Quotation: “Bha e ’na shuidhe ’s a’ bhuaile.” “A’ bhuail’ aig na h-éildearan.” Notes: term applied to the area in front of the pulpit in the Free Church, where the elders sat.
[bu̜xkɑx] Notes: said to be the word used in the Beauly area for a lad up to about 14 years old.
[bũ̟ṉɑdʹ] Notes: close fitting cap worn by women, tied with a ribbon under the chin.
[bəṉɑ:t̪ə] Quotation: buntàta gorm [bənɑtə ɡɔɾɑm]. Notes: potatoes left lying on the surface of a field and exposed to the sun and wind.
Notes: an implement for breaking down lumps of earth after the soil was turned.
[kɛ̃nɛ̃b] Notes: canvas.
Notes: shinty stick.
Quotation: 1. an caoch. 2. cù caoich. Notes: 1. rabies. 2. a dog suffering from rabies.
Notes: sometimes heard for “squint-eyed”.
Notes: somersault. [NOTES: slipped under ‘car a’ mhuiltein’.]
Quotation: an carbad. Notes: a bier in the form of a hand-barrow.
Notes: cart. Common word used here. “Càrn-lòpan”; “càrn-móine”.
Notes: a horse-drawn sledge.
Quotation: a’ cur a’ mhóine air cas-bheag. Notes: 1st lifting.
Notes: shoe-last. Also applied to the “tree” for shaping the shoe.
[cɑɾkəɫ] Quotation: cearcall na cuibhle. Notes: iron rim of cartwheel.
[cɑʴsəl] Quotation: cearsail shnàth. Notes: ball of wool. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
[cesn̪ɔxkĩnʹ] Quotation: an Ceasnachdainn. Notes: examination of knowledge of the Shorter Catechism held every year in one of the houses.
Quotation: Là na Ceisd. Notes: Friday of Communions.
Quotation: Coinneamh Cheisd [kɔnʹiçeʃtʹ].
Notes: hailstone.
Quotation: an cladh. Notes: cemetery.
[kɫ[ɑ̃ĩ]ɑṉ] Quotation: Chuir e an claimhean air an dorus. Notes: wooden sliding bolt.
Notes: buzzard.
Quotation: cloinn an dà bhràthair. Notes: 1st cousins.
Notes: a snowflake.
Quotation: a’ chluasag. Notes: the bridle of the plough. (See also srian – DMM.)
[kɫu̜ivɑu̜ɫ] Notes: common term for shinty.
Quotation: Chaidh e a cochull a’ chridhe or Theab e dhol a cochull a’ chridhe.
Quotation: Coinneamh Ràith [kɔnʹirɛ:]. Notes: seasonal meeting.
Quotation: Coinneamh Cheisd [kɔnʹiçeʃtʹ].
Quotation: Coinneamh Mhios [kɔnʹivĩɑ̃s]. Notes: monthly meeting.
[k[ɔ̃ĩ]spɔx] Notes: wasp.
Quotation: Tha e coltach ris an uisg. Notes: “It looks as if it is going to rain.”
Notes: plough-share.
Quotation: an comanachadh. Notes: Communion.
Quotation: a’ chomhachag [əxɔ̃:xɑɡ]. Notes: the owl.
[kɔrəsɡɾiɑx] Notes: heron.
[kɔrəhĩɤ̃mɑ̃ṉ] Notes: a rope-making tool.
[kɾɛlɑɡ] Notes: cleg.
[kɾiɤəɾ] Notes: a riddle.
[kɾĩɤ̃ṉɑɡ] Quotation: a’ chrionag. Notes: little finger. “Lùdag” also used.
Quotation: Bha an t-each ’na cruinn-leum. Notes: The horse was galloping.
Quotation: cù caoich. Notes: a dog suffering from rabies.
Quotation: casan cuagach. Notes: twisted, bent.
Notes: hump-backed.
Quotation: cruach fheur. Notes: haystack.
[ku̜ɤʴsṯɑɡɑx] Quotation: gaoth-chuartagach. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
[ku̟i] Quotation: cuidhe shneachd. Notes: bank of snow.
Quotation: cuireadh na bainns’. Notes: wedding invitation.
Quotation: Fhuair thu cuireadh a’ phìobaire. Notes: “You can come to the wedding, if you want to.” See Dw.
[ku̟ʃvɑ̃ɡi] Notes: object of scorn.
Notes: divot usually placed at the back of the fire when dry.
[d̪ɔ:vlw̃n̪ɑx] Notes: two year old horse.
Quotation: a’ daiseadh a’ mhoine. Notes: some time after the first lifting the peat would be shifted and put in long narrow strips to allow the wind to get at it.
Quotation: Bha ’n daorach dhearg air.
Quotation: Bha ’n daorach dhearg air.
[dʹʒe:ən̪] Notes: hobble made of twisted birch wands, put on the horse’s two front legs.
[dʹʒel] Quotation: an deil. Notes: cart axle.

[dı:bərd̪ɑ̃ṉ] Quotation: “Bha e cho luath ris an dìobartan.” Notes: thought to be the sunlight dancing on rippled water. George Moss (N. Kessock) says “air tremble or whirling, over boggy ground on a hot day”.
[dʹiɔɫidʹ] Notes: a riding saddle.
[dʹisp] Quotation: a’ diospadh. Notes: the process of smoothing horn spoons with a bit of glass.
Quotation: na dùirn. Notes: plough-handles.
Notes: hair falling over horse’s forehead.
[ḏɔ:t̪əm] Notes: a spinning-top.
[d̪ɾu̟ɡ] Notes: ball of fire in the sky, thought to be an evil omen. [NOTES: slipped under ‘dreag’.]
[d̪ɾɛən̪d̪ɤu̜n̪] Notes: wren.
Quotation: droch isean. Notes: “a bad stick” – used of a person. [NOTES: slipped under ‘droch-isean’.]
[d̪ɾoməleʃ] Notes: chain going over the saddle and attached to the cart shafts.
Notes: probable, likely.
[d̪u̜lio] Notes: pancreas (?).
Notes: gall-bladder.
Notes: ember.
Quotation: Bha éirigh mhath air a’ chloimh. Notes: the new wool next to the skin of the sheep was long, therefore the shearing was easier.
[eʃlʹıɡʹ] Quotation: Chuir iad an corp air an eislig. Notes: board(s) on which a body was stretched out.
Quotation: tigh-fhaire. Notes: a house in which a wake is being held.
Notes: a heather fire.
[fjɑu̜ɾəd̪] Notes: eyelash.
[feɡəɫ] Quotation: Tha feagal air.
[fjɑ̃n̪ɑɡ] Notes: hoodie crow.
Quotation: fear na bainnse. Notes: bridegroom.
[fjɛɾɑɡ] Notes: anger.
[fıɑx] Quotation: Feuchaidh mi dhuit e. Notes: I’ll show it to you.
[fiɑɾsɤi] Notes: dried grass, hay.
[fıɤxkılʹ] Quotation: Tha fiacail anns an àirde tuath. Notes: a short length of rainbow said to indicate an imminent storm. (Usually seen to the north – DMM.)
[fiɑx] Notes: raven.
Notes: perforated strip put on the toecap of a shoe for adornment.
[fɾwɣɑ̃ṉ] Notes: quill attached to the end of string when making shoes to enable the string to pass through the holes more easily.
Notes: spring or well. “Tobar” not used.
Quotation: “Feuch am beil thu air [ɡɑɑl] agad.” Notes: “See that you are well wrapped.”
[ɡɛ̃nʹɛ̃x] Notes: sand.
Quotation: lachan gàire. Notes: loud burst of laughter.
[ɡɑɫɑɾɡɾɤ] Notes: illness in horses which produced a running nose. (Strangles?)
[ɡw:ʴdʹɑ̃ṉ] Notes: arm. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
[ɡw:xu̜ɤʴsṯɑɡɑx] Notes: an eddying wind. [NOTES: the turned r used for the symbol which is unclear in the original.]
Quotation: (1) a’ ghaoth shios. (2) a’ ghaoth shuas. Notes: (1) the east wind. (2) the west wind.
[ɡɑɾɑɣu̜xkɑɡ] Notes: the first distilling of the whisky. “Foreshot”. Very strong (?). See Dw.
[ɡɑmũ̜ṉ] Notes: horse’s mane.
Notes: pike (fish).
Notes: hare.
Quotation: an gille. Notes: best man at a wedding.
Quotation: a’ glanadh a’ bhuntàta. Notes: cleaning, weeding.
[ɡɫw:ɑ̃ṉ] Notes: piece of potato without the eye.
Notes: lea land.
[ɡɫɔɡəɾə] Notes: a stupid person, a fool.
[ɡɫɤ:mɑx] Notes: stupid.
Notes: the joint on a horse’s foreleg corresponding to the knee.
[ɡoəɫ] Quotation: gobhal a’ chruinn. Notes: space between the two handles of a plough.
[ɡɤu̜ɾɑəɾ] Notes: the snipe. DMcK thinks it might be the curlew. Snipe in other parts.
Notes: earwig.
[ɡo:ɫɑɡ] Notes: a grape.
[ɡɾıu̟sɑx] Notes: mass of red embers.
Quotation: Bha grìs fhuachd air. Notes: He was shivering with the cold.
[ɡɾı:ʃɑx] Quotation: “Tha e grìseach.” Notes: very cold, making one shiver.
[ɡɾu̜:ɑṉ] Notes: liver.
Quotation: guc(hd)ag [ɡu̟xkɑɡ]. Notes: the shell of an egg.
